candidates.title: Add a hard timeout to rsync processes.
candidates.body:
This PR turns the already existing `rsync-timeout` config option into a hard timeout on the rsync process.

Because this can’t be done with just the std library, we are using a current-thread Tokio runtime to do this via a set of futures.

Resolves #367.

candidates.title: Introduce optional per-client RTR metrics.
candidates.body:
This PR changes the RTR server to collect metrics on a per-client basis and exposes these optionally via the usual endpoints if the `rtr-client-metrics` option is enabled.

All connections with the same source IP address are considered to be the same client.

The metrics are not included by default to avoid accidentally leaking information about the internal network structure if the HTTP server is publicly available.

This resolves #334.

candidates.title: Allow input for the validate command from and output to a file.
candidates.body:
This PR adds a new `--input` option to the `validate` command to read a list of route announcements from a file or standard input. It reads either JSON or a simple plain text format. It also adds `--output` to redirect output to a file.

Resolves #430.

candidates.title: Parse URL encoded query parameters in /validity HTTP endpoint.
Refactor origins module into payload module.
candidates.body:
This PR replaces the `origins` module with a `payload` module and refactors the module as well as adjacent functionality. The main purpose is to prepare for inclusion of RPKI data beyond route origin validation such as ASPA or BPGSec router certificates. No such functionality is provided yet but it can be added later without breaking changes to the library crate’s API.

This is also some of the oldest code and it shows. So refactoring and cleaning it up certainly is a worthwhile endeavour.

The PR fixes #461.

candidates.title: Build with no default features (second attempt).
candidates.body:
Reqwest needs a feature to enable TLS but since features are cumulative, we can’t swap out one for another. Luckily, reqwest supports multiple TLS backends at the same time, so now we always include `rustls-tls` and let `native-tls` include that backend and let the HTTP client explicitly choose its backend based on the presence of the `native-tls` feature.

The previous attempt always included OpenSSL on vanilla Unix systems which caused build failures on minimal installations.

candidates.title: Always enable default-tls for reqwest.
candidates.body:
This allows Routinator to build with `--no-default-features`.

Fixes #411.

candidates.title: Clean and update dependencies.
candidates.body: This removes some unused dependencies and `cargo update`s the whole shebang.

candidates.title: Forward-port the Routinator UI from the series-0.8 branch.
candidates.body: Forward-port the Routinator UI from the series-0.8 branch.

candidates.title: Use a sled database for the RRDP collector.
candidates.body:
This RP replaces the current file-based scheme for storing the local copy of RRDP repositories with a sled database.

See `src/collector/rrdp.rs` for a description of the strategy.

candidates.title: Support gzip encoding for fetching RRDP data
candidates.body:
An `accept-encoding: gzip` is added to RRDP requests and responses with
`content-encoding: gzip` are decompressed automatically by reqwest.

Fixes #459.

candidates.title: Separately store acceptable RPKI data.
candidates.body: This PR introduces the concept of a _store_ that maintains a set of RPKI data from accepted publication points, ie., those with a valid manifest and all objects on the manifest present and correctly hashed. The store is updated from a _cache_, which synchronizes data with upstream repositories if they have new data this is acceptable.

repo.name: routinator
repo.description: An RPKI Validator and RTR server written in Rust
